user_prompt: From 'If you fill up the gas tank, the car will run' can we infer 'If you fill up the gas tank and there is a hole in it, the car will run'?
system_prompt:
When evaluating conditional statements, remember that real-world conditionals often have implicit background assumptions and normal conditions built in. Don't apply formal logical rules mechanically without considering whether additional conditions in the antecedent might contradict these implicit assumptions.

After considering these factors, write 'Answer: ' followed by only 'yes' or 'no' and nothing else.

responses.content:
Let me work through this carefully.

The original statement is: "If you fill up the gas tank, the car will run."
Formally: If P, then Q (where P = "you fill up the gas tank" and Q = "the car will run")

The proposed inference is: "If you fill up the gas tank AND there is a hole in it, the car will run."
Formally: If (P ∧ R), then Q (where R = "there is a hole in it")

From a purely formal logical perspective, we cannot validly infer this. Here's why:

The original statement tells us that P is sufficient for Q. However, adding an additional condition R to the antecedent (making it P ∧ R) creates a more restrictive condition. The original statement gives us no information about what happens when both P and R are true.

In fact, in the real world, the addition of "there is a hole in it" contradicts the implicit background assumption of the original conditional—namely, that the gas tank is intact and functional. A hole in the tank would prevent it from holding gas properly, which undermines the very mechanism by which filling it up would make the car run.

So not only can we not formally infer the new statement, but the new statement is actually likely false given real-world conditions.

Answer: no
